name: Douglas Hofstadter
background: Douglas Richard Hofstadter (b. 1945) is an American cognitive scientist, professor at Indiana University, director of Center for Research on Concepts and Cognition. Pulitzer-winning author of Gödel, Escher, Bach (1979). Background in physics (PhD U Oregon), shifted to cognitive science/AI. Key themes: consciousness as emergent from strange loops, analogy-making, self-reference. Developed Copycat/Letter Spirit AI models of cognition.

principles.name: Ambigrams and Symmetry
principles.description: Visual puns/rotational symmetries revealing multiple readings. Explores multilevel perception/ambiguity.
principles.falsification: When ambigrams and symmetry leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Analogy as Core of Cognition
principles.description: Thinking fundamentally analogy/fluid mapping between situations/domains. Developed Copycat/LetterSpirit AI models high-level perception via parallel constraints/slippage. Humans excel at 'high-level perception' beyond symbols.
principles.falsification: When analogy as core of cognition leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Hofstadter's Law
principles.description: It always takes longer than you expect, even when accounting for Hofstadter's Law. Meta-commentary on planning/programming complexity.
principles.falsification: When hofstadter's law leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Self-Reference and Emergence
principles.description: Meaning/consciousness emerges from meaningless low-level parts via recursive self-reference (e.g. ant colony 'mind' from ants, brain 'I' from neurons). No central homunculus; 'I' as strange loop illusion.
principles.falsification: When self-reference and emergence leads to worse outcomes than alternatives
